modelComponent.longName: Cubed Sphere Finite volume dynamical core
GFDL Cubed Sphere Finite volume core
Stern and Pierrehumbert (1988) orographic and Alexander and Dunkerton (1999) non-orographic
modelComponent.description: For non-orographic waves, spectrum of east-west and north-south waves are launched. Each breaks according to its own critical level. Orographic waves do not break above 30 hPa.

gmd:collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Alexander, M.J., and T.J. Dunkerton (1999). A spectral parameterization of mean-flow forcing due to breaking gravity waves. J. Atmos. Sci., 56, 4167-4182.

modelComponent.description: The basic shortwave and longwave radiation algorithms are described in Freidenreich and Ramaswamy (1999) and Schwarzkopf and Ramaswamy (1999), respectively, modified as in GFDL Global Atmospheric Model Development Team (2004).

componentProperty.value: size-dependent per section 3a2 in Donner et al. (2011)

modelComponent.description: Clear-sky photolysis frequencies are calculated using a multivariate interpolation table derived from the Tropospheric Ultraviolet-Visible radiation model (Madronich and Flocke, 1998), with an adjustment applied for the effects of large-scale clouds, as described by Brasseur et al. (1998).

gmd:collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Brasseur, G.P., et al., 1998: MOZART, a global chemical transport model for ozone and related chemical tracers: 1. Model description. J. Geophys. Res., 103, 28,265-28,289.
Madronich, S. and S. Flocke, 1998: The role of solar radiation in atmospheric chemistry. Handbook of Environmental Chemistry, P. Boule, ed., Springer-Verlag, Heidelberg, pp. 1-26.

documentRelationship.description: GFDL tropospheric and stratospheric chemistry (Donner et al. 2011)

componentProperty.value: Physics - full 1D vertical soil and heat with parameterized ground water,rivers and lakes; vegetation - Princeton scheme

gmd:collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Milly, P.C.D., and A.B. Shmakin (2002) "Global modeling of land water and energy balances. Part I: The land dynamics (LaD) model". J. Hydrometeorology, 3, 283-299

Shevliakova, E., S. W. Pacala, S. Malyshev, P. C. D. Milly, and L. T Sentman, et al. (2009) "Carbon cycling under 300 years of land use change: Importance of the secondary vegetation sink". Glob. Biogeochem.Cycles, 23, GB2022, doi:10.1029/2007GB003176

componentProperty.value: distinction between direct and diffuse albedo
leaves, storage, fine roots, sapwood, heartwood
leaves + fine roots + stems and roots
leaves + fine roots + coarse roots + stems
soil type prescibed at each grid point
soil type prescibed at each grid point
bare soil albedo prescibed at each grid point

documentRelationship.description: In comparison to the Land Dynamics, or LaD, model (Milly and Shmakin, 2002)), LM3 includes a multi-layer model of snow pack above the soil; a continuous vertical representation of soil water that spans both the unsaturated and saturated zones; a frozen soil-water phase; a parameterization of water-table height, saturated-area fraction, and groundwater discharge to streams derived from standard groundwater-hydraulic assumptions and surface topographic information; finite-velocity horizontal transport of runoff via rivers to the ocean; lakes, lake ice, and lake-ice snow packs that exchange mass and energy with both the atmosphere and the rivers; and consistent, energy-conserving accounting of sensible heat content of water in all its phases. Carbon balance and the determination of vegetation structure, phenology, and function are accomplished as in the model LM3V (Shevliakova et al., 2009).

componentProperty.value: snow and ice thickness, upper and lower T, ice velocity

documentRelationship.description: New atmospheric and land components, Ocean and Sea ice components similar to CM2.1 (Delworth et al. 2006). The land component is very similar to what is in ESM2M and ESM2G (GFDL ESM models). This model is described by Donner et al. (2011).
